[[@frisbySociologicalImpressionismReassessment1992]]  La [relevancia de Simmel](((9oFE7EfEl))), según Frisby, ha sido a menudo malinterpretada al clasificarlo como un "sociólogo formal" en un sentido rígido. El pilar de su teoría es el concepto de "interacción" (`Wechselwirkung`), entendido como un "principio unificador fundamental" y un "proceso incesante y fluido" donde la sociedad emerge como la "suma de las interacciones sociales". Este principio se complementa con la "esencial interconexión" (`Wesenszusammengehörigkeit`), la idea de que ningún fenómeno puede entenderse de forma aislada. Este enfoque metodológico es "micro" por naturaleza; Simmel actúa como un "__flâneur__ sociológico" que recolecta "impresiones fugaces" y analiza los "detalles más insignificantes de la vida social" para encontrar en ellos "la totalidad de su significado". La sociabilidad, como forma de interacción momentánea, estilizada y centrada en sí misma, se convierte en un objeto perfecto para esta mirada "impresionista". Es en este tipo de "instantáneas" (`Momentbilder`) donde Simmel puede suspender el tiempo para revelar las formas puras de la relación humana, demostrando cómo su método es ideal para capturar la esencia de la modernidad en sus manifestaciones más sutiles y efímeras. La relevancia de Simmel, por tanto, no está en la construcción de un gran sistema, sino en la agudeza de esta perspectiva microscópica y relacional.

**The Friction of a Frictionless World: A Critical Examination of Georg Simmel's Concept of Sociability**
**The Architecture of Geselligkeit: Defining Simmel's "Play-Form" of Association**

Georg Simmel, a foundational figure in sociology, proposed the concept of "sociability" (__Geselligkeit__) as a distinct and crucial form of human interaction. Sociability is, in his formulation, the "play-form" or "art form" of association (__Vergesellschaftung__).1 Whereas most human associations are formed to achieve specific, substantive goals—economic, political, religious, or otherwise—sociability is interaction for its own sake.1 The satisfaction it offers derives not from an external outcome but from the very act of associating, from the process by which "the solitariness of the individual is resolved into togetherness".1 In its purest manifestation, sociability has "no ulterior end, no content, and no result outside itself".1

This "purposeless" nature fundamentally distinguishes it from content-driven interactions. In a business meeting or a political rally, the conversation and relationships are means to an end. In sociable gatherings, such as a dinner party, the content of the conversation is merely the "indispensable carrier of the stimulation" that allows for the lively, mutual play of personalities.1 The topics can change lightly and quickly because they are not the point; the dynamic interplay between individuals is.1

To achieve this state, sociability must operate as a kind of symbolic, artificial reality. Simmel draws a direct analogy to art and play: sociability takes its forms from the real world but leaves their "substance" and "frictional relations" behind.1 It creates an idealized "shadow world" where individuals interact not as their complete, complex selves but as "symbolic and equal personalities".4 This world is an aesthetic construct, a "symbolic play, in whose aesthetic charm all the finest and most sublimated dynamics of social existence and its riches are gathered".7

A crucial precondition for this play-form is the establishment of a "democracy of equals".8 This is not a political reality but an artificial, temporary state. To enter the world of sociability, participants must tactfully agree to suspend the objective and deeply personal qualities that differentiate them in the real world. Wealth, social position, erudition, and professional fame are to be left at the door, as are intense personal moods, excitements, or depressions.1 Because the external and egoistic interests that normally guide behavior are bracketed, a different regulator must take their place: tact. Tact becomes the essential, self-regulating mechanism that ensures the interaction remains purely sociable and does not collapse back into a content-driven, reality-based encounter.1

The repeated analogies to art and play are not merely illustrative; they reveal the core logic of the concept. __Geselligkeit__ is fundamentally an aesthetic ideal, not an empirical description. Its logic is that of an artwork, which stylizes reality for a particular effect, rather than that of a scientific model, which seeks to accurately represent reality. To critique sociability for being "unrealistic" or "idealized" is, from this perspective, to make a category error—akin to criticizing a landscape painting for not being an actual landscape. The concept functions as an ideal type, a conceptual pole against which real, messy, "impure" interactions can be measured. The critical question it provokes is not whether pure sociability exists, but what the sociological function of such an ideal is, and what it reveals about the society in which the impulse for it arises.
**The Critique of Idealism: Abstraction, Form vs. Content, and the Problem of Empiricism**

Perhaps the most persistent and foundational critique of Simmel's concept of sociability stems from his broader methodological approach, known as "formal sociology." This approach, which seeks to abstract the universal __forms__ of interaction (e.g., conflict, competition, subordination, sociability) from their variable and concrete __contents__ (the specific motives, interests, and individuals involved), has been criticized as overly idealistic, abstract, and empirically problematic.11 Simmel envisioned a "geometry of social life," where the sociologist could analyze the properties of a triad, for instance, regardless of whether its members were a family or a business committee.12

This method, however, led to a body of work that many contemporaries and later sociologists found to be "speculative, aphoristic, and stylistically careless".14 Simmel has been characterized more as a brilliant "essayist rather than a social theorist," producing impressionistic and "dilettantish" pieces that lack a single, "coherent theoretical framework".15 His work, full of literary flair and philosophical depth, often seemed more like "poetry... than sociology" to those seeking a systematic, scientific discipline.16

This abstract and essayistic style creates significant challenges for empirical application. Concepts like sociability are defined in such broad and sometimes ambiguous terms that they become difficult to operationalize or measure.18 Critics trained in more empirical traditions find Simmel's reliance on "intuitive procedures" and his apparent disregard for factual documentation to be a fundamental weakness, precluding the registration of his ideas within the bounds of conventional science.19

The core of this critique lies in the controversial analytical separation of form from content. While Simmel argued this was a necessary abstraction for analysis, critics contend it creates an artificial and untenable bifurcation.12 In reality, form and content are inextricably intertwined; one cannot exist without the other. To speak of sociability as a "pure form" risks reducing it to an "empty farce, a lifeless schematization proud of its woodenness" if it is completely detached from the threads of real life.6 Ethnographic research consistently demonstrates that even the most playful and sociable relations are deeply embedded in the "real life" content of work, family, and community, challenging the notion that form can be so cleanly excised.20

Ultimately, this critique of Simmel's idealism is a reflection of a fundamental clash between two different epistemological paradigms. Simmel's work is deeply rooted in a neo-Kantian philosophical project that asks the transcendental question, "How is society possible?".7 His goal was to identify the

__a priori__ forms and conceptual conditions that structure social experience, making society intelligible to its members. In contrast, many of his critics, particularly those who followed in the tradition of Émile Durkheim or later quantitative methodologies, evaluated his work from a more positivist standpoint. They sought testable hypotheses, causal laws, and systematic theories, and found instead a series of brilliant but unsystematic fragments.16 Therefore, the charge that sociability is "idealistic" or "unreal" is valid from an empirical perspective, but it often fails to engage with the philosophical tradition from which the concept emerges. A fair assessment must first recognize that the form/content distinction is an
__analytical__ tool, not an ontological claim about a separate existence.12 The concept's weakness as an empirical tool is a direct consequence of its strength as a philosophical ideal type.
**The Elitist Enclave: Critiques of Cultural Specificity and Social Exclusion**

While Simmel presents sociability as a universal human impulse, critics argue that the concept is deeply rooted in a specific, privileged cultural milieu, making its claims to universality suspect. The model of __Geselligkeit__ is not a generic template for human interaction but a portrait of a particular kind of social life, namely that of the European bourgeoisie and aristocracy.

Simmel himself provides the primary evidence for this critique. He traces the historical emergence of pure sociability to the French court society of the __ancien régime__. He argues that as the aristocracy was stripped of its real political power and purpose (its "content") by the monarchy, its consciousness crystallized around the pure "forms" of social interaction—etiquette, conversation, and manners—for their own sake.6 This historical origin story anchors the concept in an elite context. Consequently, critics contend that sociability is an ethnocentric model based on "Northern European, professional-class occasions".20 Simmel concedes that pure sociability is "difficult to bring off across class divides," acknowledging that the frictionless play it requires is predicated on a certain level of shared cultural understanding and background.9

The very preconditions of sociability betray its elitist foundations. The requirement to bracket serious life purposes, economic necessities, and objective social status is a luxury that is not universally available.1 For working-class individuals, whose social interactions are often inextricably linked to material survival and the "exigencies of daily life," the notion of a "purposeless" gathering is a foreign, if not impossible, ideal.20 The "play-form" of association is only accessible to those who have the time, resources, and security to treat life, even for a moment, as a game.

This reveals a deeper dynamic: the performance of sociability functions as a subtle mechanism of social closure.23 The "democracy of equals" it creates is, in practice, a highly exclusive club. Admittance requires mastering a specific set of cultural codes—"good form," wit, and above all, "tact"—which function as a form of cultural capital. Those who lack this capital, who cannot perform the effortless self-regulation required, are marked as outsiders.

This exposes a central paradox in the concept's logic. The ability to engage in "purposeless" interaction is, in itself, a purpose-driven display of status. Only those who are secure in their social and economic position can afford to "play" at being a mere personality, unburdened by such concerns. This act of bracketing reality becomes a powerful, if tacit, signal of one's elevated place within that reality. In this light, sociability is transformed from a genuine "play-form" into a sophisticated status game. Its latent purpose is the affirmation of a shared elite identity through the masterful performance of exclusive cultural norms. This connects directly to Simmel's own analysis of fashion, where the dual impulses of imitation of superiors and distinction from inferiors drive social dynamics.24 Sociability, then, can be understood as a kind of social fashion, where the style of interaction itself is the luxury good being displayed to create distinction. It is a perfect example of what it purports to exclude: a strategic interaction deeply rooted in the realities of social hierarchy.
**Power and Pretense: Reconciling Domination and Subordination with the "Democracy of Equals"**

Georg Simmel's broader sociological work offers one of the most profound and nuanced analyses of power in the classical tradition. He meticulously detailed the forms of superordination and subordination, authority, prestige, and conflict, not as static structures, but as dynamic, reciprocal forms of interaction (__Wechselwirkung__).18 For Simmel, even the most absolute domination is a social relationship that requires at least a minimal degree of participation or consent from the subordinate; without it, the relationship dissolves.26

Given this sophisticated understanding of power as a constitutive element of all sociation, the concept of sociability presents a stark paradox. It is defined precisely by the __exclusion__ of these dynamics. It is a "frictionless" world 6 populated by "symbolic and equal personalities" 4, an artificial realm where the burdens and hierarchies of real life are held in abeyance. This conceptual bracketing of power opens sociability to the critique of being politically naive and descriptively inaccurate, offering a sanitized vision of social life that ignores the structural inequalities and power dynamics that are always present, whether latently or actively, in any human encounter.18

Simmel's own formal analysis demonstrates how fragile such an egalitarian state must be. His famous examination of the dyad and the triad shows that while a two-person group can maintain a certain intimacy and balance, the introduction of a third person fundamentally alters the group's dynamic, creating a supra-individual structure that stands over and against the individuals.27 The third party can assume a variety of power-laden roles: the non-partisan mediator, the arbitrator, or, most strategically, the

__tertius gaudens__—the "third who enjoys"—benefiting from the conflict or competition between the other two.26 This analysis suggests that the stable, egalitarian "feel" of sociability is an exceptionally delicate state, perhaps only possible in a dyad and immediately threatened in any larger group.

However, to dismiss sociability as a simple oversight is to miss its crucial role within Simmel's dialectical view of modernity. His work is animated by a series of tensions: between the individual and society, freedom and constraint, subjective life and objective culture.27 The central drama of modernity, for Simmel, is the "tragedy of culture," a process whereby the objective forms created by human beings—money, law, technology, social structures—gain a life of their own and come to dominate the subjective, creative life of the individual.21

Within this tragic framework, sociability should be understood not as a description of reality, but as a __reaction__ to it. It is the manifestation of the "impulse to sociability" 3, a deeply human drive to carve out a small, fleeting world of subjective freedom, play, and un-instrumentalized connection as a refuge from the "overwhelming power of metropolitan life" 31 and the "iron cage" of an increasingly rationalized, objectified world. It is an aesthetic solution to a sociological problem. Therefore, to critique sociability for ignoring power is to misunderstand its function as a conceptual counterpoint

__to__ power. Its very idealism, its fragility, and its "frictionless" quality are the point. They highlight, by way of contrast, the pervasiveness of friction and power in modern life and the profound difficulty of achieving genuine human connection in the face of alienating objective forces.
**A Gendered World: Feminist Critiques and the Masculine Subject of Sociability**

When examined through a feminist lens, the seemingly universal and neutral form of __Geselligkeit__ reveals itself to be predicated on unstated, historically specific, and patriarchal assumptions about gender. The "pure form" of sociability is not pure at all; it is saturated with the gendered content of the society that produced it, and its formal abstraction serves to obscure its own patriarchal foundations.

Simmel's own writings on gender, while occasionally insightful in their recognition of social asymmetry, are deeply problematic. He often presented women as less differentiated, less individual, and evolutionarily "lagging behind" men.32 He described objective culture—the world of art, law, science, and politics—as "thoroughly male".33 This worldview inevitably shapes the implicit subject of his concepts. The "individual" who participates in sociability—who can detach from the "seriousness" of life for a moment of "play"—is implicitly a bourgeois male. His identity and purpose are forged in the external, "serious" public spheres of work and politics, realms historically dominated by men.34 He can afford to treat the social gathering as a leisurely game because his real-world status is secured elsewhere.

The concept's structure relies on a sharp public/private divide that mirrors patriarchal social organization. Sociability is a "play" world set apart from the "real" world of consequence. For women, who were historically confined to the domestic sphere or semi-public spaces like the salon, these social interactions were not mere play. They were a central arena for strategic work: managing household reputation, forging alliances, and securing advantageous marriages. The ability to bracket an interaction as "purposeless" is a privilege enjoyed primarily by those whose life's purpose is defined and pursued in a separate, public domain.

Applying the lens of intersectionality—a concept that, ironically, has roots in Simmel's own idea of the "intersection of social circles" 32—further shatters the illusion of sociability's "democracy of equals." Feminist theorists use intersectionality to critique how overlapping systems of oppression related to race, class, and gender create unique social positions and experiences. The experience of a social gathering for a working-class woman is fundamentally different from that of an upper-class man; the notion of them interacting as "symbolic and equal personalities" 4 is a fiction that erases these profound structural differences.

This leads to a crucial paradox. Sociability requires participants to bracket their "complete" personalities in favor of "symbolic" ones.4 But who defines which parts of the personality are "serious" and "objective" (to be bracketed) and which are suitable for "play"? Given that Simmel saw objective culture as male, the qualities set aside are typically male-coded public attributes like professional status and economic power. The qualities celebrated within sociability—amiability, charm, wit, cordiality 8—are often coded as feminine "social skills." This creates a dynamic where women are expected to excel at the performance of sociability, yet the very framework of sociability as "not serious" devalues this social and emotional labor. The male participant is viewed as a complete individual taking a recreational break, while the female participant's identity is often wholly contained and defined within this devalued sphere of "play." Thus, sociability becomes a form of interaction where men play using skills women have been socialized to perform as work, subtly reinforcing the very gender hierarchy it claims to suspend.
**The Intrusion of Reality: Erving Goffman's Interaction Order as Corrective**

If Simmel's sociability represents an idealized, philosophical model of interaction, the work of sociologist Erving Goffman provides its most powerful empirical corrective. By shifting the focus from an abstract ideal type to the concrete realities of the "interaction order"—the domain of face-to-face encounters—Goffman systematically reintroduces all the real-world friction that Simmel deliberately brackets out, effectively demonstrating that Simmel's "frictionless" world is a fragile and effortful achievement, not a natural state of play.9

Where Simmel imagines a space where external realities are suspended, Goffman shows that participants in any interaction are acutely aware of attributes created outside the gathering, such as status, merit, and power.9 The interaction order is not a free space but is governed by a complex set of pre-existing rules, moral standards, and codes of decorum that constrain behavior.9 The specific context of the interaction—its time, place, and "region"—is highly relevant to what transpires.9

This fundamental shift in perspective transforms the nature of the social actor. Simmel's "symbolic personality," engaging in interaction for mutual joy, is replaced by Goffman's strategic, and often anxious, performer. Social life is not a lighthearted play but a high-stakes "drama" in which individuals engage in "impression management" to stage a convincing performance of self.37 Goffman's famous distinction between the "front stage" (where the performance is enacted) and the "back stage" (where it is prepared) reveals the immense, hidden labor required to maintain a seamless social front.35

The core affective tone of social life consequently shifts from pleasure to peril. Simmel's sociability is characterized by "joy, relief, vivacity".1 In stark contrast, Goffman's interaction order is a site of profound "vulnerability".9 In the presence of others, we are constantly at risk of embarrassment, of having our performance discredited, of losing face. The primary goal is not shared pleasure but the successful maintenance of a shared definition of the situation to avoid the potential chaos of social disorder.

This contrast reveals a "realist" refutation of Simmel's "idealist" model. The two thinkers begin from opposing premises. Simmel starts with the human __impulse__ for sociability, a desire for connection.1 Goffman, in a more Hobbesian vein, starts with the fundamental

__problem__ of social order: how is sustained, coherent interaction possible at all?.36 For Simmel, the rules of sociability (like tact) emerge from within the play-form to sustain its pleasure. For Goffman, the rules of interaction are external constraints imposed by the macro-social structure, which individuals must skillfully navigate to avoid disaster.9 Simmel's sociability is a voluntary escape

__from__ the real world; Goffman's interaction order is the arena where the real world—with all its statuses, roles, and power dynamics—is constantly being performed and ratified __in__ every micro-level encounter. The ultimate implication of Goffman's work is that "pure sociability" is an empirical fiction. Every interaction is laden with the "content" of the self being staged and the structural rules being upheld. The appearance of a frictionless, playful encounter is not a starting point but the result of immense, hidden, and stressful dramaturgical work.
**From Play to Politics: Contrasting Sociability with Jürgen Habermas's Public Sphere**

At first glance, Simmel's __Geselligkeit__ and Jürgen Habermas's "public sphere" appear to describe related phenomena—gatherings of individuals in conversation—but they operate with fundamentally divergent logics and purposes. The public sphere, for Habermas, is an essential political domain where private individuals come together for "rational-critical debate" on matters of general concern, with the goal of forming public opinion to guide and legitimize state action.40 It is inherently purposeful and political. In stark contrast, Simmel's sociability is defined by its very lack of purpose; it is an aesthetic, a-political realm of play.1

Both concepts require the bracketing of social status. However, the reason for this bracketing reveals their different aims. In Habermas's ideal public sphere, status is disregarded to allow the "unforced force of the better argument" to prevail, creating a level playing field for reason.43 In Simmel's sociability, status is disregarded for the sake of frictionless, playful interaction, creating a level playing field for pleasure.1 Furthermore, Habermas's model is explicitly hostile to the very qualities that define sociability. He draws a sharp line between the "scientific-theoretical" and "moral-practical" validity required for rational discourse and the "aesthetic-expressive sphere," which he sees as a potential contaminant.44 The intrusion of entertainment, emotion, and spectacle into politics—what he terms "infotainment" or the "refeudalization" of the public sphere—is, for Habermas, a sign of its degradation and decline.41

Initially, this comparison suggests that sociability is a frivolous and politically impotent concept compared to the robust, critical model of the public sphere. However, a contemporary re-evaluation, particularly in light of the digital media landscape, inverts this conclusion. Critics now argue that Habermas's sterile, rationalist model fails to capture the reality of the modern "aestheticized" and "mediatized" public sphere, which is dominated by images, emotion, and play.44

Here, Simmel's social aesthetics becomes a powerful corrective. His focus on "typification" (the reliance on generalized, simplified images of others) and "gamification" (the structuring of interaction as play) provides a more suitable analytical toolkit for understanding online communication, which is often more ludic and image-based than rational-critical.44 While Habermas's theory can only diagnose the rise of memes, viral content, and emotional appeals as a

__decline__ from a rational ideal, Simmel's framework allows for an analysis of __how__ this new public sphere functions on its own aesthetic and playful terms, without a normative bias against it. The "gamification" of online life, from social media likes to political messaging, is perfectly captured by Simmel's concept of the "play-form of association." In a surprising twist, the supposed "flaws" of sociability—its focus on aesthetics, play, and surface-level interaction—become its analytical strengths. Simmel, the a-political aesthete, may have inadvertently provided a more potent set of tools for analyzing 21st-century political communication than Habermas, the preeminent theorist of the public sphere.

**Simmel's Ghost in the Machine: Contemporary Re-evaluations in the Digital Age**

While many of Simmel's concepts were seen as overly abstract or impressionistic by his contemporaries, they have experienced a remarkable revival in the 21st century, proving to be exceptionally well-suited to analyzing the nature of digital society. The very features of his sociology that were once critiqued as flaws—its abstraction, its focus on form over content, and its detachment from physical reality—have become its greatest analytical strengths in the virtual world of the internet.

Simmel's 1908 essay "The Intersection of Social Circles" (famously translated as "The Web of Group-Affiliations") is now seen as astonishingly prescient.45 His theory describes how modern individuals, liberated from the confines of a single primary group, come to stand at the intersection of multiple, overlapping, and often geographically dispersed social circles. This process, he argued, creates a highly complex and differentiated personality, as no two individuals share the exact same pattern of group affiliations.45 This is a near-perfect theoretical description of "networked individualism," the dominant mode of social organization in the internet age, where individuals navigate a complex web of online and offline connections, from family and local friends to global special-interest groups and professional networks.45

The core concept of "sociation" itself—the fluid, dynamic process of forming and re-forming relationships—aptly describes the nature of digital interaction. Online communities can be temporary and fleeting, based on shared interests or issues, embodying the flexible, interest-based interactions Simmel saw as characteristic of modern life.46

Even sociability, with its idealist trappings, finds a new home online. The "playful" and "symbolic" aspects of __Geselligkeit__ map directly onto online interactions where users adopt avatars and curated personas, bracketing their "real selves" to engage in performative exchanges. The focus on the __form__ of interaction—likes, shares, retweets, memes—often overshadows deep substantive content, resembling a "gamified" version of sociability where the pleasure of the interaction itself is paramount.44

Finally, Simmel's classic social type of "The Stranger" serves as a powerful metaphor for the contemporary social media user. The stranger is defined by a unique synthesis of nearness and remoteness; they are physically present in a group but not organically a part of it, affording them a unique objectivity.29 The networked individual is similarly situated: intimately connected to a global network of "friends" and followers, yet potentially experiencing a "peculiarly contemporary loneliness".14 Their belonging is not rooted in physical co-presence but is fluid and technologically mediated, a state of being simultaneously inside and outside of countless social circles.47 The digital world, a realm of pure information, symbols, and representations, has in many ways become the empirical reality that Simmel's abstract, formal sociology was waiting for. The "shadow world" of "symbolic personalities" he described has found its material expression in the servers and screens of the 21st century.
**Synthesis and Conclusion: The Enduring Value of a Flawed Ideal**

The critiques leveled against Georg Simmel's concept of __Geselligkeit__ are both numerous and valid. When judged by the standards of empirical, descriptive sociology, sociability is an idealized abstraction, an elitist and culturally specific model, a gendered construct that naively brackets the pervasive influence of power.16 It fails as a comprehensive map of how all people interact in all situations. To dismiss it on these grounds, however, is to misapprehend its purpose and, in doing so, to miss its profound and enduring value.

The true function of sociability is not descriptive accuracy but analytical power, which it achieves precisely through its idealism. As a sociological "ideal type," it establishes a conceptual benchmark—a "zero point" of pure, frictionless, purposeless interaction.9 It is against this theoretical baseline that the "impurities" of real-world sociation—the intrusions of power, purpose, inequality, and conflict—can be most clearly identified, measured, and analyzed. Its abstraction is what gives it utility as a comparative tool.

Ultimately, the concept of sociability is diagnostic. It is a lens crafted to bring the central tensions of modernity into focus. The palpable gap between the ideal of a free, playful, and authentic association and the empirical reality of an increasingly instrumentalized, rationalized, and power-laden social world is the very essence of what Simmel called the "tragedy of culture".21 The concept gives form to the modern longing for un-alienated connection in a world dominated by objective, often oppressive, forces. It articulates a desire that is as relevant today as it was a century ago.

The surprising resurrection of Simmel's ideas in the digital age is a testament to the lasting power of his formal, relational approach.45 It demonstrates that even his most "speculative" and "essayistic" formulations contain deep structural insights that can be redeployed to illuminate social forms he could never have imagined.14 The critiques of

__Geselligkeit__, therefore, do not invalidate it. On the contrary, they clarify its proper and most powerful role in the sociological toolkit: not as a map of the social world, but as a finely crafted instrument that reveals the frictions, contradictions, and tragedies of that world with unparalleled sharpness. It is in its "flaws," in its elegant detachment from reality, that its deepest sociological insight resides.

El "ambiente sin fricciones" de Simmel es un logro frágil que requiere esfuerzo. El actor social de Simmel, una "personalidad simbólica" que busca el goce mutuo, es reemplazado por el **actor estratégico y a menudo ansioso de Goffman**, un "performer" que gestiona impresiones en un "drama" de altas apuestas. La distinción entre "escenario" y "trastienda" de Goffman revela el inmenso trabajo oculto para mantener una fachada social. El tono afectivo de la vida social pasa del placer al **peligro**: la interacción es un sitio de "vulnerabilidad", con el riesgo constante de vergüenza y de "perder la cara". El objetivo principal no es el placer compartido, sino mantener una definición compartida de la situación para evitar el caos social. Este contraste muestra una refutación **"realista"** del modelo **"idealista"** de Simmel. Simmel parte del "impulso" humano de sociabilidad, mientras que Goffman lo hace del **"problema central del orden social"**. Para Simmel, las reglas de la sociabilidad emergen para sostener el juego. Para Goffman, son limitaciones externas de la estructura macrosocial, que los individuos deben sortear hábilmente. La "sociabilidad pura" sería una ficción empírica; toda interacción está cargada de contenido y reglas estructurales. La apariencia de un encuentro lúdico y sin fricción es el resultado de un **trabajo dramatúrgico** inmenso y estresante.

Aunque la sociabilidad de Simmel y la **esfera pública de Jürgen Habermas** describen interacciones de grupo, tienen lógicas y propósitos divergentes. La esfera pública de Habermas es un dominio **político** donde los individuos buscan un **"debate crítico-racional"** para formar una opinión pública que influya en el estado. Es inherentemente propositista y política. La sociabilidad de Simmel es **puramente estética y apolítica**. Ambos conceptos requieren la suspensión del estatus social, pero por razones distintas: en Habermas, es para que prevalezca la "fuerza no forzada del mejor argumento"; en Simmel, es por el placer de la interacción sin fricciones. El modelo de Habermas es hostil a las cualidades de la sociabilidad, pues la intrusión del entretenimiento y la emoción en la política es una "degradación" de la esfera pública. Aunque inicialmente esto sugiere que la sociabilidad es frívola, una reevaluación actual, especialmente en el contexto digital, invierte esta conclusión. El modelo racionalista de Habermas no logra capturar la realidad de la esfera pública moderna "estetizada" y "mediatizada". El enfoque de Simmel en la **"tipificación"** (simplificación de imágenes) y la **"gamificación"** (estructura de la interacción como juego) de su estética social ofrece una herramienta analítica más adecuada para la comunicación online, que es más lúdica y basada en imágenes que racional-crítica. Las "falencias" de la sociabilidad, como su énfasis en la estética y el juego, se convierten en sus **fortalezas analíticas para comprender la nueva esfera pública**, que se rige por su propia lógica estética y lúdica.

Las críticas a la sociabilidad de Simmel son válidas. Como modelo empírico, es una **abstracción idealizada, elitista, culturalmente específica y con sesgo de género**, que ignora el poder. No es un mapa exhaustivo de todas las interacciones. Sin embargo, su valor perdura en su **propósito analítico** a través de su idealismo. Como **"tipo ideal"** sociológico, establece un punto de referencia para identificar y analizar las "impurezas" de la sociación en el mundo real, como la intromisión del poder, el propósito, la desigualdad y el conflicto. Su abstracción le confiere utilidad como herramienta comparativa. El concepto de sociabilidad es **diagnóstico**. Permite enfocar las tensiones centrales de la modernidad: la brecha entre el ideal de una asociación libre y auténtica y la realidad de un mundo social cada vez más instrumentalizado y dominado por el poder. Representa la "tragedia de la cultura" de Simmel y la nostalgia moderna por una conexión no alienada. El resurgimiento de sus ideas en la era digital demuestra el poder de su enfoque formal y relacional. Las críticas a la _Geselligkeit_ no la invalidan, sino que clarifican su función más potente: no como un mapa del mundo social, sino como un instrumento que revela las fricciones, contradicciones y tragedias de ese mundo con agudeza. Es en sus "defectos" y su elegante desapego de la realidad donde reside su más profunda perspicacia sociológica.

A useful analogy for the limits of formalism for games is the shift in biology from the **taxonomic system of species classification** (such as that of Louis Agassiz) to the evolutionary model (see Menand, 2001). Up until Darwin, most biologists (and scientists generally) proceeded according to (in fact, from) predetermined, formal categories, such as species, which separated specific categories of flora and fauna by a hard, bright line. Darwin, however, through his theory of natural selection, upended that entire formalist position by proposing that **at a very fundamental level, species did not exist, at least not in that sense**. Species was only a relative means of distinguishing a group of living things that shared, on average, certain characteristics. This meant that investigations in biological variation needed to proceed with a clear eye to the range of contingency operating on the ground, beyond adaptation (as Stephen Jay Gould and Richard Lewontin continued to argue more recently; see Gould & Lewontin, 1979), instead of contenting themselves with “plausible stories” that reflected assumptions about categories of species (and their features) more than fact. Critics of Simmel's distinction between form and content in modernity have highlighted various aspects. Simmel's concept of the tensions between form and content has been viewed as tragic (Elliott & Turner, 2012). This distinction, rooted in Kant's differentiation between form and content, forms the basis of Simmel's 'formal sociology' (Lee & Silver, 2012). However, some scholars argue that to remain relevant, **Simmel's dualities of social-human and form-content need to be reinterpreted outside his metaphysical framework, aligning more with contemporary research in psychology and learning theory** (Kamolnick, 2001).

Moreover, Simmel's focus on the contradiction and conflict between subject content and object form, particularly in relation to money, has been critiqued for painting a pessimistic view of modern society (Zhang & Zhang, 2021). The transition from the distinction between form and content to life and form in Simmel's works has also been noted, indicating a shift in his philosophical approach (Vernik, 2019). Simmel's concepts of form and content are seen as intricately intertwined within the object of study itself, reflecting a deeper connection between social theory and the theory of society (Staudacher, 2023).

Furthermore, Simmel's approach to ethics, endings, and futures has been scrutinized for potentially losing momentum by compartmentalizing the study of his impact on sociology, rather than integrating content and form to drive a more cohesive narrative (Featherstone, 2020). While Simmel's analysis often emphasizes the reciprocity between form and content in social interactions, some argue that he did not explicitly include the material object in his discussions, potentially limiting the scope of his analysis (Cederholm, 2009).

In summary, critics have raised concerns about the relevance and interpretation of Simmel's distinction between form and content in modern society, suggesting the need for a reevaluation of his concepts in light of contemporary research and societal developments.

[[@araujoCalleDesigualdadesInteraccionales2016]]; [[@araujoIgualdadLazoSocial2013]] Kathya Araujo fundamenta la relevancia del concepto de sociabilidad a través de su teoría sobre las "desigualdades interaccionales". Su punto de partida es que para entender la desigualdad, es necesario primero llenar de significado concreto el principio de igualdad en una sociedad determinada. Sostiene que, para el caso chileno, a las dimensiones tradicionales de la igualdad (política y económica) se debe agregar una tercera, crucial: la **"igualdad en el lazo social"**. Esta se mide por la calidad del trato que un individuo recibe en las interacciones cotidianas, independientemente de su posición social. La violación de este principio da lugar a las **"desigualdades interaccionales"**, que son las experiencias de trato injusto en la vida diaria y que, según la autora, se han convertido en el "barómetro principal" desde el cual se leen las otras desigualdades más estructurales. Es aquí donde el concepto de **sociabilidad** adquiere una relevancia central. Araujo justifica explícitamente su enfoque en estas micro-interacciones por "el peso que tiene en ellas [las sociedades latinoamericanas] la sociabilidad". Para sostener esta afirmación, se apoya en una larga tradición del pensamiento latinoamericano —desde los "ensayos del carácter" (Paz) y los "textos fundamentales del pensamiento social" (Freyre, Buarque de Holanda) hasta análisis contemporáneos (Da Matta, Lechner)— que ha destacado la sociabilidad como un elemento **"central para entender la dimensión de integración social"** y, a la vez, como el **"escenario privilegiado de los juegos dirimentes de poder social"**. Dado que la sociabilidad es este escenario principal, la dimensión de la interacción se convierte en el espacio donde se juega lo que ella, citando a Rancière, denomina la **"verificación de la igualdad"**. Es en el trato cotidiano, en el tejido de la sociabilidad, donde los individuos comprueban si la promesa abstracta de igualdad es una realidad o una "falacia tremenda". Araujo distingue su enfoque de las teorías del reconocimiento (Honneth), argumentando que la demanda principal que observa no es de reconocimiento de la identidad, sino de ser **"bien tratado en las interacciones ordinarias"**, poniendo el foco en la interacción misma y no en la intersubjetividad subyacente. Por lo tanto, en su marco, la sociabilidad no es un tema secundario o privado, sino el terreno empírico fundamental donde se experimenta la justicia, se constituyen los juicios sobre la sociedad y se define la adhesión o el desapego al colectivo.
